The ravines on the tidally-heated forest moon of Xylophia-IV-e, as you've described, are formed by the combination of seismic cracks and the erosion caused by the brackish rivers. The intense geological activity of the moon, due to its proximity to the gas giant, results in a constant reshaping of its landscape. The ravines are a prime example of the moon's dynamic geology.

Lava tubes are a common feature within the sheer gorge faces of these ravines. Formed during past volcanic eruptions, these tubes are created when lava flows through the landscape, leaving behind hollow, tunnel-like structures as it cools and solidifies. The erosion caused by the brackish rivers has exposed many of these lava tubes, revealing them in the walls of the ravines.

These lava tubes provide unique habitats for a variety of life forms, including plants and animals adapted to the dark, sheltered environment within the tubes. They also offer opportunities for exploration and discovery, as they may hold secrets about the moon's geological history and hidden ecosystems. In an ecopunk adventure, these lava tubes could serve as a setting for thrilling encounters and unexpected discoveries, as the protagonists delve into the hidden depths of the moon's geology.
